label: 043.  Stephen Elliott to William H. W. Barnwell -- May 14, 1840
description: Letter from Stephen Elliott to William H. W. Barnwell asking advice about his recent election to the bishopric of Georgia.  Included is a copy of the letter informing Elliott of his election. May 14, 1840.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: Columbia May 14th 1840 My Dear William, You will perceive from the newspapers that I have been called, by a vote of the Georgia Convention, to the Episcopate of that Diocese--that is my duty! [illegible] the will of God? Can you help me, my dear Brother, to answer these questions? Pray for me & write me your opinion upon the following topics. 1st. How for is it right to decline the office of Bishop, seeing that it [hole in MS] a degree of the Ministry which cannot be attained except thro' a call of this kind? 2ly. What do you think of the fields? of usefulness? a comparative? point of view, both present & future [illegible], or my present one?[End Page 1] 3.ly. How should I be giving more glory to God, by accepting or refusing, under the circumstances in which I have been recently placed with respect to the Episcopal office in this state? If I know mine own heart at all, my duty is what I desire to know & understand. [illegible] that calls me, I trust that I am ready to place myself, without any regard to circumstances of consequences. Pray give this matter for the sake of the [illegible] a solemn & prayerful consideration & answer me as one having no [illegible] nor interest in the matter-- I send you a copy of the letter of the clerical committee so that you may have before you all the facts of a case. Very affly your Brother Stephen Elliott P.S. As nobody [that had?] the least authority ever hinted such a thing to me, I am entirely uncommitted in word or deed to the Georgia Church. [End Page 2] (copy of letter) Clarkesville, Geo. May 5 1840 Revd & Dear Sir, It becomes my pleasing duty, in conformity with a Resolution of G. Convention of this Diocese, to inform you of your unanimous election to the Episcopate thereof, with a salary of Two Thousand Dollars per ann. independent of a parochial cure--leaving it optional with you to accept the Rectorship of a new Parish [?], associated with Christ Church Savannah, under the name & title of St. John[']s Church, with the understanding that the Rector of the two Churches are to alternate in the services and to maintain the unity of the present Parish Church. This arrangement has been suggested by the vestry of Christ Church, with the consent of the Rector, with a view to increase the income of the B[ishop to] $3000, as well as to secure his services, during such portions of time as are not taken up in a performance of duties of the Episcopate. There will be no limitation or restriction placed upon the Bishop's movement but he will be left free to make such arrangements as in his judgment the interests of the Diocese may [hole in MS]. Individually for [illegible], as well as on behalf of that portion of the Church which [illegible] represent, or beg leave to express the Earnest hope, that the good Spirit of him who presides over the Church will incline your Heart towards us & induce our acceptance of an office which affords such favorable opportunities of serving your generation according to the will of God, by advancing the interests of his kingdom. [End Page 3] Rev. S. Elliott Jr May 1840 requesting advice as to accepting the Episcopate of Georgia I wrote in the negative <COLUMBIA SC MAY 14> To the Revd. Wm. H. Barnwell Charleston So. Carolina The required testimonial is signed & ready for transmission to different standing committees, as soon as your decision shall be known-- with very great esteem we [illegible] Edw. Neufville Edw. E. Ford Seneca G. Bragg Clerical Memb. of the Standg Committee [End Page 4]
